answers.answer: There are several considerations for your situation. The first is the obvious one of  large fluid intake. If you can cut back on that, you may solve the problem easily. You may have some kidney damage that has resulted in both your hypertension and your frequent urination. A third issue is  a condition called “diabetes insipidus” which results in the production of large volumes of dilute urine. This can be diagnosed by measuring the specific gravity of your urine after you have been fasting for 12 hours. I think that a visit to a nephrologist (the subspecialist who  deals with the medical – as opposed to the surgical-problems in kidneys).S.A.Liroff, M.D.

question: I am a 24 year old female.  I have been dealing with urinary frequency for about 7 months.  During waking hours, I usually urinate twice every hour.  At night, I wake up 6 times to urinate.  I recently found out that I have hypertension and I'm taking HCTZ for that.  I'm also taking Lexapro daily.  I have been tested for diabetes, thyroid problems, and tumors.  No one has a clue.  Any info?
title: Urinary frequency at a young ago
